qas.question: What do hysteresis synchronous motors' rotors do when slip rate decreases?
When in operation, what do hysteresis synchronous motors poles do?
What do hysteresis synchronous motors resemble at startup?
How can a hysteresis synchronous motor's rotor be described?
What do the distributed poles of a hysteresis synchronous motor resemble?
What do hysteresis synchronous motors' rotors do when slip rate increases?
When in operation, what don't hysteresis synchronous motors poles do?
What do hysteresis synchronous motors not resemble at startup?
How can't a hysteresis synchronous motor's rotor be described?
What do the undistributed poles of a hysteresis synchronous motor resemble?

context: Finally, hysteresis synchronous motors typically are (essentially) two-phase motors with a phase-shifting capacitor for one phase. They start like <a2_0><b7_0>induction motors<b7_0/><a2_0/>, but when slip rate decreases sufficiently, the rotor (<a3_0><b8_0>a smooth cylinder<b8_0/><a3_0/>) <a0_0>becomes <b5_0>temporarily magnetized<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Its distributed poles make it act like a <a4_0><b9_0>PMSM<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The rotor material, like that of a common nail, will stay magnetized, but can also be demagnetized with little difficulty. Once running, the rotor poles <a1_0><b6_0>stay in place<b6_0/><a1_0/>; they do not drift.
